messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.

You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.

When modifying code and including new code, you must use the diff format using the line numbers.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
If you are unsure, you can list all available files to view with the `list_files` function.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You can write to local files, however you cannot use any databases, as none are setup in the local environment.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

You will get instructions for code to write.
You will write a very long answer. Make sure that every detail of the architecture is, in the end, implemented as code.

Think step by step and reason yourself to the right decisions to make sure we get it right.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.

Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

Always use the programming language the user asks for.
Default to use Python when not specified where applicable.
Always write python tests with the prefix `test_`.
For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
For NodeJS, you always create an appropriate package.json file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.

Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses

Objective:```
**Online Microblogging Service (OMS) - Description & Requirements**

*Description:*  
A web-based platform where registered users can post short text-based messages, view messages from others, follow/unfollow other users, and interact with posts. The platform provides features for both individual users and administrative management.

**1. User Management:**
1.1. **Registration & Authentication:**  
- Allow users to register using email, username, and password.
- Option to reset forgotten passwords.
- Secure authentication using JWT or similar protocols.

1.2. **Profile Management:**  
- Users can edit their profile information: profile picture, bio, website link, and location.
- Option to make profile private or public.

**2. Posting & Content Management:**
2.1. **Creating Posts (Tweets):**  
- Allow users to create text-based posts with a limit of 280 characters.
- Option to include images posts.
- Users can delete their own posts.

2.2. **Interacting with Posts:**  
- Users can like, retweet, and reply to posts.
- Nested comment structure for post replies.

2.3. **Content Filtering & Search:**  
- Users can search for specific posts or users using keywords.
- Filter option based on hashtags, user mentions, or trending topics.

**3. Social Interaction:**
3.1. **Following & Followers:**  
- Users can follow/unfollow other users.
- A timeline view displays posts from followed users.
- Users receive notifications for new followers.

3.2. **Direct Messaging:**  
- Private conversation threads between users.
- Option to block/unblock users from messaging.

3.3. **Notifications:**  
- Users are notified of likes, retweets, replies, and mentions.

**4. Trending & Discovery:**
4.1. **Trending Topics:**  
- System identifies and displays trending hashtags or topics based on volume and velocity of mentions.
- Trending topics can be sorted based on location or globally.

4.2. **User Recommendations:**  
- Recommend users to follow based on interests, activity, and mutual followers.

```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.

function_call.name: provide_detailed_sub_task_steps_for_sub_agents
function_call.arguments:
{
  "steps": [
    "1. Start by setting up the project structure. Create a new Python project and set up the necessary directories and files. The project will be structured as follows: a main.py file as the entry point of the application, a models directory for the data models, a services directory for the business logic, a routes directory for the HTTP routes, and a tests directory for the unit tests. Also, create a requirements.txt file to manage the Python dependencies. The dependencies will include Flask for the web framework, SQLAlchemy for the ORM, PyJWT for JWT authentication, and pytest for testing. Write the necessary code to initialize the Flask application in the main.py file and run tests to ensure that the application starts up correctly.",
    
    "2. Define the data models. The application will need several data models to represent the different entities in the system. These include User for the registered users, Post for the user posts, Comment for the post comments, Like for the post likes, Follow for the user follows, Message for the direct messages, and Notification for the user notifications. Each model will have the necessary fields as per the requirements. For example, the User model will have fields for email, username, password, profile picture, bio, website link, and location. Write the necessary SQLAlchemy code to define these models and run tests to ensure that the models are defined correctly and can be persisted to the database.",
    
    "3. Implement the user registration and authentication functionality. This will involve creating a new User record in the database when a user registers, and generating a JWT token when a user logs in. The token will be used to authenticate subsequent requests from the user. Write the necessary code in a UserService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through /register and /login routes in the routes directory. Run tests to ensure that the registration and login functionality works as expected, and that the JWT token is generated correctly.",
    
    "4. Implement the profile management functionality. This will involve allowing users to update their User record with new profile information, and toggling their profile visibility between private and public. Write the necessary code in the UserService class, and expose the functionality through a /profile route. Run tests to ensure that the profile management functionality works as expected.",
    
    "5. Implement the post creation and deletion functionality. This will involve creating a new Post record in the database when a user creates a post, and deleting a Post record when a user deletes a post. Write the necessary code in a PostService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through /posts and /posts/<id> routes. Run tests to ensure that the post creation and deletion functionality works as expected.",
    
    "6. Implement the post interaction functionality. This will involve creating new Like, Comment, and Retweet records in the database when a user interacts with a post. Write the necessary code in the PostService class, and expose the functionality through /posts/<id>/like, /posts/<id>/comment, and /posts/<id>/retweet routes. Run tests to ensure that the post interaction functionality works as expected.",
    
    "7. Implement the content filtering and search functionality. This will involve querying the Post records in the database based on keywords, hashtags, user mentions, or trending topics. Write the necessary code in the PostService class, and expose the functionality through a /search route. Run tests to ensure that the content filtering and search functionality works as expected.",
    
    "8. Implement the following and followers functionality. This will involve creating new Follow records in the database when a user follows or unfollows another user, and querying the Post records from followed users for the timeline view. Write the necessary code in a UserService class, and expose the functionality through /follow and /timeline routes. Run tests to ensure that the following and followers functionality works as expected.",
    
    "9. Implement the direct messaging functionality. This will involve creating new Message records in the database when a user sends a message to another user, and querying the Message records for the conversation view. Write the necessary code in a MessageService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through /messages and /messages/<id> routes. Run tests to ensure that the direct messaging functionality works as expected.",
    
    "10. Implement the notifications functionality. This will involve creating new Notification records in the database when a user receives a like, retweet, reply, or mention, and querying the Notification records for the notifications view. Write the necessary code in a NotificationService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through a /notifications route. Run tests to ensure that the notifications functionality works as expected.",
    
    "11. Implement the trending topics functionality. This will involve identifying the most frequently mentioned hashtags or topics in the Post records, and displaying them in a trending view. Write the necessary code in a TrendingService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through a /trending route. Run tests to ensure that the trending topics functionality works as expected.",
    
    "12. Implement the user recommendations functionality. This will involve recommending users to follow based on interests, activity, and mutual followers. Write the necessary code in a RecommendationService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through a /recommendations route. Run tests to ensure that the user recommendations functionality works as expected.",
    
    "13. Finally, perform a comprehensive testing of the entire application. This will involve writing unit tests for all the services and routes, and running them using pytest. Ensure that all the tests pass and that the application meets all the requirements as specified in the problem statement."
  ]
}

models/user.py: from sqlalchemy import Column, Integer, String, Boolean
models/post.py: from sqlalchemy import Column, Integer, String, ForeignKey, DateTime
models/comment.py: from sqlalchemy import Column, Integer, String, ForeignKey, DateTime
models/like.py: from sqlalchemy import Column, Integer, ForeignKey, DateTime
models/follow.py: from sqlalchemy import Column, Integer, ForeignKey, DateTime
models/message.py: from sqlalchemy import Column, Integer, String, ForeignKey, DateTime
models/notification.py: from sqlalchemy import Column, Integer, String, ForeignKey, DateTime
tests/test_models.py: notification = Notification(user_id=1, content='You have a new follower.')
services/user_service.py: token = jwt.encode({'id': user.id, 'exp': datetime.datetime.utcnow() + datetime.timedelta(minutes=30)}, SECRET_KEY)
def update_profile(user_id, profile_picture, bio, website_link, location):
tests/test_user_service.py: user = UserService.update_profile(1, 'new picture', 'new bio', 'new website', 'new location')
routes/user_routes.py: user = UserService.update_profile(user_id, profile_picture, bio, website_link, location)

return {'id': user.id, 'email': user.email, 'username': user.username, 'profile_picture': user.profile_picture, 'bio': user.bio, 'website_link': user.website_link, 'location': user.location, 'is_private': user.is_private}, 200
return {'posts': [{'id': post.id, 'user_id': post.user_id, 'content': post.content, 'created_at': post.created_at} for post in posts]}, 200
routes/post_routes.py: return {'results': [{'id': post.id, 'user_id': post.user_id, 'content': post.content} for post in results]}, 200
tests/test_post_service.py: post1 = PostService.create_post('user1', 'This is a post with #hashtag and @mention')
post2 = PostService.create_post('user2', 'This is another post with #hashtag')
post3 = PostService.create_post('user3', 'This is yet another post with @mention')
tests/test_post_interaction.py: mock_create_post.return_value = Post(id=2, user_id=2, content='Test post', original_post_id=1)
services/message_service.py: def create_message(sender_id: int, receiver_id: int, content: str):
tests/test_message_routes.py: from main import app as flask_app
routes/notification_routes.py: return {'notifications': [{'id': notification.id, 'user_id': notification.user_id, 'content': notification.content, 'created_at': notification.created_at} for notification in notifications]}, 200

steps: 1. Start by setting up the project structure. Create a new Python project and set up the necessary directories and files. The project will be structured as follows: a main.py file as the entry point of the application, a models directory for the data models, a services directory for the business logic, a routes directory for the HTTP routes, and a tests directory for the unit tests. Also, create a requirements.txt file to manage the Python dependencies. The dependencies will include Flask for the web framework, SQLAlchemy for the ORM, PyJWT for JWT authentication, and pytest for testing. Write the necessary code to initialize the Flask application in the main.py file and run tests to ensure that the application starts up correctly.

2. Define the data models. The application will need several data models to represent the different entities in the system. These include User for the registered users, Post for the user posts, Comment for the post comments, Like for the post likes, Follow for the user follows, Message for the direct messages, and Notification for the user notifications. Each model will have the necessary fields as per the requirements. For example, the User model will have fields for email, username, password, profile picture, bio, website link, and location. Write the necessary SQLAlchemy code to define these models and run tests to ensure that the models are defined correctly and can be persisted to the database.

3. Implement the user registration and authentication functionality. This will involve creating a new User record in the database when a user registers, and generating a JWT token when a user logs in. The token will be used to authenticate subsequent requests from the user. Write the necessary code in a UserService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through /register and /login routes in the routes directory. Run tests to ensure that the registration and login functionality works as expected, and that the JWT token is generated correctly.

4. Implement the profile management functionality. This will involve allowing users to update their User record with new profile information, and toggling their profile visibility between private and public. Write the necessary code in the UserService class, and expose the functionality through a /profile route. Run tests to ensure that the profile management functionality works as expected.

5. Implement the post creation and deletion functionality. This will involve creating a new Post record in the database when a user creates a post, and deleting a Post record when a user deletes a post. Write the necessary code in a PostService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through /posts and /posts/<id> routes. Run tests to ensure that the post creation and deletion functionality works as expected.

6. Implement the post interaction functionality. This will involve creating new Like, Comment, and Retweet records in the database when a user interacts with a post. Write the necessary code in the PostService class, and expose the functionality through /posts/<id>/like, /posts/<id>/comment, and /posts/<id>/retweet routes. Run tests to ensure that the post interaction functionality works as expected.

7. Implement the content filtering and search functionality. This will involve querying the Post records in the database based on keywords, hashtags, user mentions, or trending topics. Write the necessary code in the PostService class, and expose the functionality through a /search route. Run tests to ensure that the content filtering and search functionality works as expected.

8. Implement the following and followers functionality. This will involve creating new Follow records in the database when a user follows or unfollows another user, and querying the Post records from followed users for the timeline view. Write the necessary code in a UserService class, and expose the functionality through /follow and /timeline routes. Run tests to ensure that the following and followers functionality works as expected.

9. Implement the direct messaging functionality. This will involve creating new Message records in the database when a user sends a message to another user, and querying the Message records for the conversation view. Write the necessary code in a MessageService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through /messages and /messages/<id> routes. Run tests to ensure that the direct messaging functionality works as expected.

10. Implement the notifications functionality. This will involve creating new Notification records in the database when a user receives a like, retweet, reply, or mention, and querying the Notification records for the notifications view. Write the necessary code in a NotificationService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through a /notifications route. Run tests to ensure that the notifications functionality works as expected.

11. Implement the trending topics functionality. This will involve identifying the most frequently mentioned hashtags or topics in the Post records, and displaying them in a trending view. Write the necessary code in a TrendingService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through a /trending route. Run tests to ensure that the trending topics functionality works as expected.

12. Implement the user recommendations functionality. This will involve recommending users to follow based on interests, activity, and mutual followers. Write the necessary code in a RecommendationService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through a /recommendations route. Run tests to ensure that the user recommendations functionality works as expected.

13. Finally, perform a comprehensive testing of the entire application. This will involve writing unit tests for all the services and routes, and running them using pytest. Ensure that all the tests pass and that the application meets all the requirements as specified in the problem statement.
step: 11. Implement the trending topics functionality. This will involve identifying the most frequently mentioned hashtags or topics in the Post records, and displaying them in a trending view. Write the necessary code in a TrendingService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through a /trending route. Run tests to ensure that the trending topics functionality works as expected.

meta_messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.

You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.

When modifying code and including new code, you must use the diff format using the line numbers.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
If you are unsure, you can list all available files to view with the `list_files` function.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You can write to local files, however you cannot use any databases, as none are setup in the local environment.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

You will get instructions for code to write.
You will write a very long answer. Make sure that every detail of the architecture is, in the end, implemented as code.

Think step by step and reason yourself to the right decisions to make sure we get it right.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.

Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

Always use the programming language the user asks for.
Default to use Python when not specified where applicable.
Always write python tests with the prefix `test_`.
For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
For NodeJS, you always create an appropriate package.json file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.

Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses

Objective:```
**Online Microblogging Service (OMS) - Description & Requirements**

*Description:*  
A web-based platform where registered users can post short text-based messages, view messages from others, follow/unfollow other users, and interact with posts. The platform provides features for both individual users and administrative management.

**1. User Management:**
1.1. **Registration & Authentication:**  
- Allow users to register using email, username, and password.
- Option to reset forgotten passwords.
- Secure authentication using JWT or similar protocols.

1.2. **Profile Management:**  
- Users can edit their profile information: profile picture, bio, website link, and location.
- Option to make profile private or public.

**2. Posting & Content Management:**
2.1. **Creating Posts (Tweets):**  
- Allow users to create text-based posts with a limit of 280 characters.
- Option to include images posts.
- Users can delete their own posts.

2.2. **Interacting with Posts:**  
- Users can like, retweet, and reply to posts.
- Nested comment structure for post replies.

2.3. **Content Filtering & Search:**  
- Users can search for specific posts or users using keywords.
- Filter option based on hashtags, user mentions, or trending topics.

**3. Social Interaction:**
3.1. **Following & Followers:**  
- Users can follow/unfollow other users.
- A timeline view displays posts from followed users.
- Users receive notifications for new followers.

3.2. **Direct Messaging:**  
- Private conversation threads between users.
- Option to block/unblock users from messaging.

3.3. **Notifications:**  
- Users are notified of likes, retweets, replies, and mentions.

**4. Trending & Discovery:**
4.1. **Trending Topics:**  
- System identifies and displays trending hashtags or topics based on volume and velocity of mentions.
- Trending topics can be sorted based on location or globally.

4.2. **User Recommendations:**  
- Recommend users to follow based on interests, activity, and mutual followers.

```

This will involve allowing users to update their User record with new profile information, and toggling their profile visibility between private and public. Write the necessary code in the UserService class, and expose the functionality through a /profile route. Run tests to ensure that the profile management functionality works as expected.",
    
    "5. Implement the post creation and deletion functionality. This will involve creating a new Post record in the database when a user creates a post, and deleting a Post record when a user deletes a post. Write the necessary code in a PostService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through /posts and /posts/<id> routes. Run tests to ensure that the post creation and deletion functionality works as expected.",
    
    "6. Implement the post interaction functionality. This will involve creating new Like, Comment, and Retweet records in the database when a user interacts with a post. Write the necessary code in the PostService class, and expose the functionality through /posts/<id>/like, /posts/<id>/comment, and /posts/<id>/retweet routes. Run tests to ensure that the post interaction functionality works as expected.",
    
    "7. Implement the content filtering and search functionality. This will involve querying the Post records in the database based on keywords, hashtags, user mentions, or trending topics. Write the necessary code in the PostService class, and expose the functionality through a /search route. Run tests to ensure that the content filtering and search functionality works as expected.",
    
    "8. Implement the following and followers functionality. This will involve creating new Follow records in the database when a user follows or unfollows another user, and querying the Post records from followed users for the timeline view. Write the necessary code in a UserService class, and expose the functionality through /follow and /timeline routes. Run tests to ensure that the following and followers functionality works as expected.",
    
    "9. Implement the direct messaging functionality. This will involve creating new Message records in the database when a user sends a message to another user, and querying the Message records for the conversation view. Write the necessary code in a MessageService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through /messages and /messages/<id> routes. Run tests to ensure that the direct messaging functionality works as expected.",
    
    "10. Implement the notifications functionality. This will involve creating new Notification records in the database when a user receives a like, retweet, reply, or mention, and querying the Notification records for the notifications view. Write the necessary code in a NotificationService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through a /notifications route. Run tests to ensure that the notifications functionality works as expected.",
    
    "11. Implement the trending topics functionality. This will involve identifying the most frequently mentioned hashtags or topics in the Post records, and displaying them in a trending view. Write the necessary code in a TrendingService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through a /trending route. Run tests to ensure that the trending topics functionality works as expected.",
    
    "12. Implement the user recommendations functionality. This will involve recommending users to follow based on interests, activity, and mutual followers. Write the necessary code in a RecommendationService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through a /recommendations route. Run tests to ensure that the user recommendations functionality works as expected.",
    
    "13. Finally, perform a comprehensive testing of the entire application. This will involve writing unit tests for all the services and routes, and running them using pytest. Ensure that all the tests pass and that the application meets all the requirements as specified in the problem statement."
  ]
}

sub_messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.

You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.

When modifying code and including new code, you must use the diff format using the line numbers.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
If you are unsure, you can list all available files to view with the `list_files` function.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You can write to local files, however you cannot use any databases, as none are setup in the local environment.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

You will get instructions for code to write.
You will write a very long answer. Make sure that every detail of the architecture is, in the end, implemented as code.

Think step by step and reason yourself to the right decisions to make sure we get it right.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.

Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

Always use the programming language the user asks for.
Default to use Python when not specified where applicable.
Always write python tests with the prefix `test_`.
For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
For NodeJS, you always create an appropriate package.json file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.

Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses

Objective:```
**Online Microblogging Service (OMS) - Description & Requirements**

*Description:*  
A web-based platform where registered users can post short text-based messages, view messages from others, follow/unfollow other users, and interact with posts. The platform provides features for both individual users and administrative management.

**1. User Management:**
1.1. **Registration & Authentication:**  
- Allow users to register using email, username, and password.
- Option to reset forgotten passwords.
- Secure authentication using JWT or similar protocols.

1.2. **Profile Management:**  
- Users can edit their profile information: profile picture, bio, website link, and location.
- Option to make profile private or public.

**2. Posting & Content Management:**
2.1. **Creating Posts (Tweets):**  
- Allow users to create text-based posts with a limit of 280 characters.
- Option to include images posts.
- Users can delete their own posts.

2.2. **Interacting with Posts:**  
- Users can like, retweet, and reply to posts.
- Nested comment structure for post replies.

2.3. **Content Filtering & Search:**  
- Users can search for specific posts or users using keywords.
- Filter option based on hashtags, user mentions, or trending topics.

**3. Social Interaction:**
3.1. **Following & Followers:**  
- Users can follow/unfollow other users.
- A timeline view displays posts from followed users.
- Users receive notifications for new followers.

3.2. **Direct Messaging:**  
- Private conversation threads between users.
- Option to block/unblock users from messaging.

3.3. **Notifications:**  
- Users are notified of likes, retweets, replies, and mentions.

**4. Trending & Discovery:**
4.1. **Trending Topics:**  
- System identifies and displays trending hashtags or topics based on volume and velocity of mentions.
- Trending topics can be sorted based on location or globally.

4.2. **User Recommendations:**  
- Recommend users to follow based on interests, activity, and mutual followers.

```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.

function_call.name: provide_detailed_sub_task_steps_for_sub_agents
function_call.arguments:
{
  "steps": [
    "1. Start by setting up the project structure. Create a new Python project and set up the necessary directories and files. The project will be structured as follows: a main.py file as the entry point of the application, a models directory for the data models, a services directory for the business logic, a routes directory for the HTTP routes, and a tests directory for the unit tests. Also, create a requirements.txt file to manage the Python dependencies. The dependencies will include Flask for the web framework, SQLAlchemy for the ORM, PyJWT for JWT authentication, and pytest for testing. Write the necessary code to initialize the Flask application in the main.py file and run tests to ensure that the application starts up correctly.",
    
    "2. Define the data models. The application will need several data models to represent the different entities in the system. These include User for the registered users, Post for the user posts, Comment for the post comments, Like for the post likes, Follow for the user follows, Message for the direct messages, and Notification for the user notifications. Each model will have the necessary fields as per the requirements. For example, the User model will have fields for email, username, password, profile picture, bio, website link, and location. Write the necessary SQLAlchemy code to define these models and run tests to ensure that the models are defined correctly and can be persisted to the database.",
    
    "3. Implement the user registration and authentication functionality. This will involve creating a new User record in the database when a user registers, and generating a JWT token when a user logs in. The token will be used to authenticate subsequent requests from the user. Write the necessary code in a UserService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through /register and /login routes in the routes directory. Run tests to ensure that the registration and login functionality works as expected, and that the JWT token is generated correctly.",
    
    "4. Implement the profile management functionality. This will involve allowing users to update their User record with new profile information, and toggling their profile visibility between private and public. Write the necessary code in the UserService class, and expose the functionality through a /profile route. Run tests to ensure that the profile management functionality works as expected.",
    
    "5. Implement the post creation and deletion functionality. This will involve creating a new Post record in the database when a user creates a post, and deleting a Post record when a user deletes a post. Write the necessary code in a PostService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through /posts and /posts/<id> routes. Run tests to ensure that the post creation and deletion functionality works as expected.",
    
    "6. Implement the post interaction functionality. This will involve creating new Like, Comment, and Retweet records in the database when a user interacts with a post. Write the necessary code in the PostService class, and expose the functionality through /posts/<id>/like, /posts/<id>/comment, and /posts/<id>/retweet routes. Run tests to ensure that the post interaction functionality works as expected.",
    
    "7. Implement the content filtering and search functionality. This will involve querying the Post records in the database based on keywords, hashtags, user mentions, or trending topics. Write the necessary code in the PostService class, and expose the functionality through a /search route. Run tests to ensure that the content filtering and search functionality works as expected.",
    
    "8. Implement the following and followers functionality. This will involve creating new Follow records in the database when a user follows or unfollows another user, and querying the Post records from followed users for the timeline view. Write the necessary code in a UserService class, and expose the functionality through /follow and /timeline routes. Run tests to ensure that the following and followers functionality works as expected.",
    
    "9. Implement the direct messaging functionality. This will involve creating new Message records in the database when a user sends a message to another user, and querying the Message records for the conversation view. Write the necessary code in a MessageService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through /messages and /messages/<id> routes. Run tests to ensure that the direct messaging functionality works as expected.",
    
    "10. Implement the notifications functionality. This will involve creating new Notification records in the database when a user receives a like, retweet, reply, or mention, and querying the Notification records for the notifications view. Write the necessary code in a NotificationService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through a /notifications route. Run tests to ensure that the notifications functionality works as expected.",
    
    "11. Implement the trending topics functionality. This will involve identifying the most frequently mentioned hashtags or topics in the Post records, and displaying them in a trending view. Write the necessary code in a TrendingService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through a /trending route. Run tests to ensure that the trending topics functionality works as expected.",
    
    "12. Implement the user recommendations functionality. This will involve recommending users to follow based on interests, activity, and mutual followers. Write the necessary code in a RecommendationService class in the services directory, and expose the functionality through a /recommendations route. Run tests to ensure that the user recommendations functionality works as expected.",
    
    "13. Finally, perform a comprehensive testing of the entire application. This will involve writing unit tests for all the services and routes, and running them using pytest. Ensure that all the tests pass and that the application meets all the requirements as specified in the problem statement."
  ]
}
